metadata.case_name: Chawla and Mukhtiara v. State of Haryana

facts.text: Jagga had three sons: Bishna, Ram Lal and Har Lal. Ram Dia, Dal Singh and Ram Singh (deceased) were sons of Bishna. Accused: Ram Lal and sons Chawla and Dhanna; Har Lal, son Puran, grandson Mukhtiara.

During consolidation operations in village Deora, dispute over 4-1/4 acres plot. Consolidation Officer allotted to Bishna; Additional Director, Consolidation set aside on May 4, 1968, allotted to Ram Lal and Har Lal.
Bishna died; deceased (his sons) moved High Court under Art. 226 to quash Director's order. High Court dismissed petition on July 14, 1971, upheld Director's order.
On October 4, 1971, Assistant Collector ordered demarcation and delivery of possession to allottees (accused) per Director's order, and mutation in their favour.

On October 5, 1971, Kanungo demarcated land, delivered symbolical possession of cropped fields (Kila Nos. 129/7, 129-17/1, 129/14, 129/16), actual possession of uncropped fields including Khasra No. 129-6/2 to accused Ram Lal and Har Lal.

Deceased did not submit to delivery of possession; instituted suit in Civil Court at Kaithal, obtained ex parte interim injunction restraining accused from taking possession, served on Ram Lal on November 5, 1971.

On November 11, 1971, at about 11 a.m., Ram Dia, Dal Singh and Ram Singh went to fields with ploughs. Dal Singh reaping chari crop, Ram Singh ploughing, Ram Dia on round. Six accused arrived: Puran and Ram Lal with suas (iron-spiked sticks), Dhanna with gandasa, Har Lal, Mukhtiara and Chawla with lathis. Har Lal exhorted to kill; Chawla, Puran, Ram Lal assaulted Ram Dia; Ram Singh rescued, assaulted by Dhanna and Mukhtiara; Dal Singh interceded, all accused assaulted him. Eyewitnesses: Smt. Mali, Nasib Singh, Shadi. Accused fled with weapons.
Ram Dia died at spot; Dal Singh died after admission in Civil Hospital Kaithal; Ram Singh expired November 13, 1971 in Medical College Hospital, Rohtak.
Sessions Judge convicted Chawla, Puran, Mukhtiara to death u/s 302/34 IPC; also u/s 302/149 on three counts, life; u/s 148, 1 year. Others convicted u/s 302/149, 34, 148, life on capital charge.

High Court commuted Puran's death to life (unclear which fatal injury by him); confirmed death for Chawla (Ram Dia murder), Mukhtiara (Ram Singh); maintained convictions u/s 302/149 for Ram Lal, Har Lal, Dhanna.
Occurrence in Kila No. 6/1, not 6/2 (disputed); fields intermingled. Kanungo's report Ex.PJJ confirms actual possession of 129-6/2 to accused.
Ram Dia armed with stick, provoked by dealing blows to Har Lal.
Chawla's examination u/s 342 CrPC: Deceased ploughing, uprooting crops; Har Lal confronted, Ram Dia hit Har Lal with lathi, then assaulted.
Ram Dia autopsy: 8 injuries, 6 punctured; Injury 8 (depression frontal/parietal bones) attributed to Chawla's lathi, individually fatal per trial but not per committal court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the death sentences awarded to Chawla and Mukhtiara are justified in view of alleged mitigating circumstances, or should be commuted to life imprisonment.

petitioner_arguments.text: Cause of tragedy traced to unreasonable, stubborn conduct of deceased in retaking/retaining possession after final allotment to accused.
Violence erupted due to deceased ploughing actual possession fields like Kila 6/2; Ram Dia provoked by dealing blows with stick to Har Lal.
For Chawla, unclear if fatal injury caused by him; unreasonable to award death for one of three fatal injuries with lathi when punctured wound causers got lesser penalty.
Chawla (25) and Mukhtiara (24) raw youths acting under instigation of father Har Lal; death sentence hovered for 1 year 10 months.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Vivian Rodrick v. State of West Bengal; Gurdip Singh v. State of Punjab; State of Maharashtra v. Naglya Dhavu Kongil; State of Bihar v. Pashupati Singh; Gajanand v. State of U.P.

respondent_arguments.text: None of circumstances are extenuating; accused went armed with determination to kill, succeeded in cold-blooded triple murder; no leniency.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Brij Bhukhan v. State of U.P.; Mizaji v. State

respondent_arguments.text: Exhortation by Har Lal not ground for not inflicting capital sentence; delay due to protracted proceedings not ground for reduction.

court_reasoning.text: Tragedy probably precipitated by deceased's insistence on cultivation/possession despite final allotment and delivery to accused; deceased kept dispute alive post-HC dismissal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Disputed land intermingled; actual possession of Kila 6/2 delivered to accused.

court_reasoning.text: Chawla caused only one injury (Injury 8) with lathi to Ram Dia; not dominant role, comparable to Har Lal/Ram Lal who caused punctured wounds but got lesser sentence; medical evidence contradictory.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Injury 8 possibly not fatal per earlier testimony.

court_reasoning.text: Chawla and Mukhtiara immature youths acting under instigation of elder Har Lal; prolonged mental agony from death sentence (over 2 years since committal).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Recognized mitigating factors; modern penological trends favour mercy.

court_reasoning.text: In totality, circumstances tilt scales in favour of life imprisonment; not enough singly under old standards, but collectively palliate offence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Courts recognize these as valid mitigation grounds.

holdings.text: Death sentences of Chawla and Mukhtiara commuted to imprisonment for life due to totality of mitigating circumstances.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court commuted the death sentences of appellants Chawla and Mukhtiara to imprisonment for life, considering totality of mitigating circumstances including provocation by deceased, limited role of Chawla, youth of appellants, instigation by elder, and prolonged mental agony.
outcome.relief_granted: Death sentences commuted to life imprisonment

key_quotes.text: The circumstances considered above have long been recognised by courts as valid grounds for mitigating the sentence. They are not innovations.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: In their totality, they tilt the judicial scales in favour of life rather than putting it out.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Prolonged mental torture suffered by Chawla and Mukhtiara on account of their being constantly haunted by the spectre of death for the last one year and 10 months.
key_quotes.speaker: court
